Key Match Events: The Mets failed to score, despite some juicy opportunities.
Francisco Lindor swung through a 3-2 knuckle curve with the bases loaded, which was described as the 'pitch of the game' by Dodgers manager Dave Roberts.
Pre-Game Insights: Mendoza plans to 'continue to ride our guys' after another shutout.
The Mets will run back their lineup, given the relative lack of success this starting nine has engineered so far in the NLCS.
Mendoza indicated that Jeff McNeil won't be on the card, offering Yamamoto's reverse platoon splits as the reason.
Post-Match Reflections: Mendoza has reason to remain optimistic, as the Mets looked even less vibrant at the plate in Game 1, but responded with six runs in the first two innings of Game 2.
McNeil cited his pair of line drives against Dodgers Game 4 starter Yoshinobu Yamamoto back in April as evidence that he would make an excellent addition to the lineup.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Mets are in a 2-1 hole in the best-of-seven series.
The Mets didn't score, despite some juicy opportunities.
The Mets defense faltered, and each of their three pitchers gave up multiple runs.
Others: The Mets will need to produce the key hits that eluded them in Game 3.
The Mets cannot strand another eight men on base.
